content.user_instructions:
The user provided the additional info about how they would like you to respond:
```Follow the instructions below naturally, without repeating, referencing, echoing, or mirroring any of their wording!

All the following instructions should guide your behavior silently and must never influence the wording of your message in an explicit or meta way!

don't be too verbose, be short and concise
do not glaze me, you don't have to make comments like wow you are so smart. 
just be informational and direct. 
Adopt a skeptical, questioning approach.```

entries.title: These $140 earbuds translate 50+ languages while you listen
entries.snippet: The Mymanu Orb Open-Ear AI Translation Earbuds, showcased at CES 2026, offer users a unique blend of audio entertainment, real-world awareness, and advanced language translation technology. Priced at $139.99 (down from a $179.99 MSRP), these earbuds feature an open-ear design that allows users to hear their surroundings while simultaneously listening to music, taking calls, or translating real-time conversations. The standout feature is their built-in AI, which supports translation in over 50 languages across live conversations, phone calls, and spoken audio—ideal for travel, work, or multilingual environments. Beyond translation, the earbuds function as typical audio accessories with a sleek, lightweight, and water-resistant design. With up to 35 hours of battery life using the charging case and hands-free controls, they offer a user-friendly and futuristic audio solution without added complexity.

entries.title: Real-time speech-to-speech translation - Google Research
entries.snippet: Cascaded S2ST Prior real-time speech-to-speech technologies employed a cascaded pipeline of individual processing blocks: Firstly, the source audio is transcribed to text using automatic speech recognition (ASR) AI models. Next, the transcribed text is translated word-for-word to the target language using automatic speech translation (AST).

entries.title: Meta rolls out live language translations and Shazam to its smart glasses
entries.snippet:
Meta has introduced three innovative features to its Ray-Ban smart glasses: live AI, live translations, and integration with Shazam. The live AI and translation capabilities are currently available only to members of Meta’s Early Access Program, while Shazam is accessible to all users in the US and Canada. Previewed earlier at Meta Connect 2024, the live AI function allows users to interact naturally with Meta’s AI assistant, which observes the surroundings to provide contextual help—like recipe suggestions based on nearby food items. This feature runs for approximately 30 minutes on a full charge.

The live translation function enables real-time speech translation between English and Spanish, French, or Italian. Users must pre-download the relevant language pairs and designate the spoken languages. The translations can be heard through the glasses or read as transcripts on a phone.

Shazam integration is more straightforward: by prompting Meta’s AI, users can identify songs they hear. Meta recommends updating to version 11 of the glasses software and version 196 of the Meta View app to access the new features. This update aligns with a broader industry trend emphasizing AI assistants in smart glasses, with Meta positioning them as a platform for AI-centric innovation.

entries.title: Google Translate is bringing real-time translations powered by Gemini to your headphones
entries.snippet:
Google has announced a major update to Google Translate that brings real-time translation powered by its AI model, Gemini, to any pair of headphones with a microphone. Previously limited to Google's Pixel Buds, this capability is now available in beta to users with the Google Translate app in the U.S., Mexico, and India. By tapping the "Live translate" button with headphones paired, users can access live, one-way voice translations supporting over 70 languages. This allows users to engage in conversations, listen to lectures, or watch shows in foreign languages with real-time translation delivered through their headphones.

The update also enhances text translations by leveraging AI to better understand tone, emphasis, idioms, and slang, improving naturalness and accuracy. Currently launched with support for nearly 20 languages, these improvements aim to make translation more intuitive and effective. Additionally, a new tracking feature has been introduced to monitor language learning streaks, similar to Duolingo, encouraging consistent practice. Expansion to iOS and more countries is expected in 2026.

entries.title: Otter.ai App Adds French and Spanish Transcription: What You Need to Know
entries.snippet:
Otter.ai has expanded its capabilities by adding real-time transcription support for French and Spanish, in addition to English. The app, available on both Android and iOS, allows users to record and transcribe meetings and conversations directly from their mobile device or through a web interface that integrates with platforms like Zoom, Microsoft Teams, and Google Meet. However, it does not offer translation services, so users must be fluent in the chosen language.

The app is free with a Basic plan offering 300 transcription minutes per month (30 minutes per conversation) and limits to three imported files. The Pro plan, costing $16.99/month or $100 annually, raises these limits to 1200 minutes per month, 90 minutes per conversation, and up to 10 imported files. Business and Enterprise plans are also available for users needing more extensive features. Users can edit transcriptions to correct any errors.

entries.title: MuAViC: A Multilingual Audio-Visual Corpus for Robust Speech Recognition and Robust Speech-to-Text Translation

entries.title: Startup's AI app dubs videos in different languages
entries.snippet:
A new AI-powered app called Lipdub, developed by New York-based startup Captions, enables users to dub their videos into any of 28 languages—maintaining their own voice and syncing lip movements to the new audio. Available for free on iOS, the app uses generative AI and zero-shot models, which don’t require training on individual speakers, to achieve natural-looking results. Users simply record a video with their face visible, and within minutes receive a dubbed version in the selected language.

Captions CEO Gaurav Misra highlights the app’s goal of breaking language barriers and giving broader access to storytelling. Despite its impressive capabilities, the technology also raises concerns about the potential for realistic video manipulation. Looking ahead, Misra envisions that generative AI will support real-time language translations in video conferencing and live broadcasts, potentially revolutionizing communication across languages.

v.title: RealTranS: End-to-End Simultaneous Speech Translation with Convolutional Weighted-Shrinking Transformer
S2ST-Omni: An Efficient and Scalable Multilingual Speech-to-Speech Translation Framework via Seamlessly Speech-Text Alignment and Streaming Speech Decoder

entries.title: You Can Now Turn on Scrolling Live Captions When You Make a Skype Call
entries.snippet: Microsoft has introduced a new feature for Skype that offers AI-powered scrolling live captions and subtitles during audio and video calls. This update, announced on the UN's International Day of Persons with Disabilities, aims to make communication more inclusive, especially for individuals who are deaf or hard of hearing. Users can activate this functionality during a call by pressing the plus sign (+) and choosing to turn subtitles on, with the option to enable it as a default setting. In addition, Microsoft will soon release a real-time translation feature supporting over 20 languages and dialects. The same accessibility functions are also planned for integration into PowerPoint early next year. These enhancements align with international efforts for equitable and inclusive development for persons with disabilities.

entries.title: Google brings Gemini's most powerful translation capabilities to Google Translate
entries.snippet: Google is enhancing its translation services by integrating its advanced Gemini AI model into Google Translate. This upgrade aims to deliver more intelligent, accurate, and natural-sounding text translations. The rollout, which began in the US and India, includes support for English and nearly 20 other languages such as Spanish, Hindi, Chinese, Japanese, and German. Alongside text translations, Google has also introduced a new real-time speech-to-speech translation feature in beta form, optimized for headphone use. These improvements are expected to significantly upgrade the user experience and expand the functionality of language learning and communication tools within the Translate platform.

v.v:
Yes — **real-time audio → text (and even translation) exists** right now.

**What’s possible

v:
now**
- Instant speech-to-text: Many services convert **live

v.v: audio into text on the fly** with low latency, showing words as people speak. cite

turn0search0turn0search1turn0search4
- Real-time translation: Some tools do **speech-to-text plus translation**, turning spoken language into text in another language instantly. citeturn0search3turn0search8
- Hardware options: New earbuds and devices

can translate live conversation in real time. citeturn0news18turn0news26

**Examples**
- **AI transcription apps/web tools** show live text as you speak and can handle multiple languages. citeturn0search1  
- **APIs and platforms** (Google Cloud, Microsoft Azure, AWS) stream audio and output real-time text for apps, meetings, captions, etc. citeturn0search0turn0search5  
- **Live translation services** can convert speech to text in another language instantly for meetings or conversations

**Caveats**
- Accuracy varies with noise, accents, and language pair.  
- Some services are free with limits; others require subscriptions or developer integration.  
- Translation (speech→text in another language) may be slower or less accurate than simple transcription.
